issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Test scenario;
- select scaling group
- select "quick scale" from "more actions"
- enter value above current max
- change value to be under previous max.
- notice max stays at higher value and will be changed now, even if it didn't need to be.
I noticed this when I had a typ-o in the desired field.
fields.summary: Quickscale dialog leaves increased max in place

comments.body: Assigned to Jerry since I thought you worked on Jenny's latest logic for this box. If not, assign to Ean.

Last I heard this was the desired behavior. Do you think it would be better to track desiredCapacity, as long as it didn't fall below the original max? The same will apply to Min... once it moves down you can't bring it back up. 

I think the right answer is to make min/max adjustable as well, so you can pull them back to acceptable bounds if you need to. Already have code in there for it, just have to toggle a model attribute to tell the template to use it.

"I" think if we imagine the min and max as rubber bands that we can push lower or higher, but they snap back to the original value, that would be helpful to the user. Simply letting those value be set to manually bring them back won't help if they don't remember the original. I think Jenny was going for something fairly automatic here and what I'm suggesting just adds to that. Maybe wait for her feedback when she gets back.
I agree with the rubberbands. Stand by...

Actually there's a chicken-and-egg problem with that:

1) dc > max... max goes up - min stays at original value
2) then change dc to < min - min goes down, and max rubberbands back to original
3) try bumping max back up where you had it - min reverts back to original

So with the rubberband, by moving dc up and down, you can really only move min OR max to new bounds, not both. Maybe what's needed is a control to 'lock' one and/or the other in place and disable the behavior when you have it where you want it. But really, from a UX perspective it might just be more confusing than spinners on all three.
Pushed to team/console/EUCA-6970 for test drive and discussion.

I was wrong - this is sort of going to work. Example:

min = 2, max = 4, dc = 2

set dc to 8 - max jumps to 8
set dc to 1 - min jumps to 1, max stays at 8
set dc to 3 - min and max stay at new values

set dc to 2 - min reverts back to 2
set dc to 4 - max reverts back to 4

Setting dc to anything > old max sets max to that. Anything < old max leaves new max unchanged. dc == old_max resets max.
Setting dc to < old min set min to that. > old min leaves min unchanged. dc == old min resets min.

So, almost. The question now is what if you bump up from max 4 to max 8, but want dc set to 4. Truth table looks something like:

dc                              | max | min
------------------------------------------
>max                          | set     | x
<min                           | x        | set
=old max                     | reset | x
=old min                      | x       | reset
>old min && <old max | x        | x

So you can't set dc to old max without resetting max, or min to old min without resetting min.
[~jpommer], [~dkavanagh], [~jloza].  To me the solution should be in line with what AWS does when you do this via command line.

We may be making things unnecessarily complicated here. What happens in AWS CLI when you do set desired capacity over max AS group size? 

I would like us to not have a bunch of logic in the code that rubberbands the max and/or min. If we raise or lower the max or min as a result of changing the desired capacity, let's just flag that change visually (I'll mock something up) and the user can always cancel the dialog if they effed something up beyond repair. That is why GUIs have cancel buttons.

AWS does not have this functionality in their console. Comparing this to CLI tools is not appropriate either.
This is simply something I noticed when I had a typo in the desired box that caused my max to be very high. I reset it to a good value and the max stayed very high. My only option was to cancel the dialog and retry. I came up with rubber band solution to make life easier for users.

We need to be careful about doing things users do not expect. I can see how typos can happen, and this leads me to believe that as always the best UX is the simplest. We should just not allow people to set a desired capacity higher than their current max (or lower than their current min). We should inform them in the validation error message that they should use the Edit Scaling Group option to change max/min values.

Citiation: EUCA-5167

I agree that setting DC is one thing, and changing the min/max boundaries are another entirely. It would be pretty easy to  turn quickscale back into what it was originally, and use the current implementation as a base for an edit dialog without the "rubberbanding"... just plain input boxes that do what you tell them to do and validate to keep you honest. 
Just give the word.

Yeah, we have an edit scaling group dialog already that [~eans] is implementing, so they should just go there if they want to do more than change desired capacity. Proceed with this one (be sure validation error message reflects what we've been talking about, please)

I mentioned my concerns about this when we first discussed quickscale changing the values. To me, quickscale should enforce the min/max, not alter it. If the plan is to turn that back off then I'm 100% in agreement.
Removed behaviors, keeping desired capacity within the bounds set by min/max.

Hang on, network is down again. I'll push as soon as I can.

commit a63e5cb8202212cf0d7988beee236dd900fd99fa
Author: Jerry Pommer <jpommer@gmail.com>
Date:   Fri Jul 19 16:59:22 2013 -0500

    EUCA-6970
    Removed exotic behavior, keeping desired_capacity within the bounds of min/max.
If desired value is put more than the {{Maximum}} value, it shows warning and the {{Scale group}} button becomes inactive. Marking as fixed.
